block.p: In 1887, William Henry Jackson's photographs of Yellowstone were a critical factor in the United States Government's decision to make it the country's first national park. Now the United Nations Environment Program is holding a large photography competition that it hopes will aid its efforts to save the planet from those who inhabit it.

The contest, "Focus on Your World," is in conjunction with the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development in Rio de Janeiro from June 1 to 12. Winning photographs will be exhibited at the conference, and afterward, 206 of them will be shown around the world.

Now the United Nations Environment Program is holding a large photography competition that it hopes will aid its efforts to save the planet from those who inhabit it.

The contest, "Focus on Your World," is in conjunction with the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development in Rio de Janeiro from June 1 to 12. Winning photographs will be exhibited at the conference, and afterward, 206 of them will be shown around the world.
"The processes of environmental abuse are as destructive as nuclear war and far less easy to avert," said Dr. Mostafa K. Tolba, executive director of the Environment Program.

On the entry form for the contest, the organization says it expects that many entries will be preserved in a photographic library that will provide "a powerful visual presentation of today's most pressing environmental problems."

For would-be contestants who need ideas on what to cover, these are among the subjects the United Nations conference will address next year: the protection of the atmosphere (climate change, depletion of the ozone layer, air pollution); protection of land resources (combating deforestation, soil loss, desertification and drought); conservation of biological diversity; protection of freshwater resources, and of oceans, seas and costal areas, and the use and development of their living resources.

Other topics are environmentally sound management of biotechnology and hazardous wastes; prevention of illegal traffic in toxic products and wastes; improvement in the quality of life and human health, and improvement in living and working conditions of the poor by eradicating poverty and stopping environmental degradation.
Canon is a major sponsor of the contest. Other supporters are Japan Airlines, Varig Brazilian Airlines, Eastman Kodak and the International Photographic Council.

U.N. officials are asking contestants to look at their pictures as donations to a cause rather than a commercial promotion. Indeed, entrants should examine the contest's rules carefully because if their pictures win, they will have to release all long-term rights to them. But the contest does not skimp on prizes, which will be given in three divisions.

In the professional division, the first prize will be $20,000; second prize, $10,000; third prize, $5,000, and 20 honorable mentions, $1,000 each. Winners of the top three prizes will also receive Canon EOS-1 cameras; each person meriting honorable mention will get a Canon EOS-100.
In the amateur division, the first prize will be $10,000; second prize, $5,000; third prize, $2,000, and 70 honorable mentions, a Canon Sure Shot Max.

In the children's division (under 16 years old), first prize will be $1,000 and second prize, $500. In addition, there will be special prizes for 100 photographs by children, with details to be announced later.

First- and second-prize winners in all categories will be invited on an expense-paid trip to the awards ceremony in Brazil. The children who win first and second prize may be accompanied by one parent each.
All pictures must have been taken between Jan. 1, 1990, and the entry deadline, Feb. 29, 1992. Entrants under the age of 21 must have a parent's signature on the entry form.

Entry forms and more information are available from Canon distributors or the United Nations Environmental Program at (800) 677-6645. Rules on picture returns are specific: "No entries, prints or slides will be returned to entrants. No receipt of entry will be sent to the entrant." John Durniak is a freelance writer, editor and consultant on photography.
